content: generally post update if all mail is marked as junk/spam it is the result of defective injected spam/junk functions for an antivirus program. If you antivirus has such functions, try turning them off and see if the issue resolves.

creator: paul.truzzi

content:
The message is telling you that you have selected to use encrypted connection with the outgoing mail server and the server and Thunderbird do not share any encryption algorithms. This is very common with old servers that have remained on old versions of software and outdated security for years, often decades old security is what private mail servers are using unfortunately.

However I am really confused, because when I look up the mail server settings for your provider on their web site https://telnetcommunications.com/support/how-to/basic-email-setup None of the server names they say to use match those in the error message.

I suggest you check both your incoming account and the outgoing account on outgoing servers (SMTP) and make sure you are actually using the setting your provider requires.
creator: MattAuSupport

content:
is the email you are displaying containing specific font size and widths? While the message readibng pane is accessible from the developer console, it responds to the CSS in the message, which may well over ride what you are trying to set.

The background colour is one of those thing that many email clients from big players like Microsoft and Apple specify in the message, along with the users choice of font (which is often very very wrong outside their personal system) and font colour

You might do better if you change the setting to allow emails to specify other fonts but those you choose, and force the readers default colours in the HTML style section of the settings.
creator: MattAuSupport

content: Rather than focus on each question, I'll share some basics: - Thunderbird displays the password as it exists. That is, if the password appears as a long code, that is the actual password. Gmail is a good example of that. - the password is displayed as-is without masked characters because your Thunderbird has the option of a primary password. If you do not want the passwords visible, use a primary password.
creator: davidsk

creator: intellogo

content: that is because gmail, like some other providers, provides (insists) on a unique password for each device from which you access gmail. that password was inserted by google. if you setup on another PC, it will get a different code.
creator: davidsk

content:
Thanks for the info. I get your point, and I'm assuming you're not referring to the 16 character Google App Passwords features which can be used for specific apps, manually decided and used by the user.

If Gmail automatically inserts that long password into the password section for the connected email account in Thunderbird, and it's a very long code which me being the user can't understand, then I'm not able to understand what's the point of Thunderbird having a facility to show it to me anyway?

If you could let me know that, how would it help an end user to see a different super long password is what I'd like to understand from your point?
creator: intellogo

content: Quite simply, the software was developed first, and the service is still useful, and it would be a waste of developer time to modify the code to only show what the user entered, as it is possible that some email providers may allow the code to be copied to other devices. Attempting to stay ahead of that would be a fool's errand.
creator: davidsk

content: The permissions.sqlite and content-prefs.sqlite files store the permissions for what remote content can be displayed. If you can find those files in another profile, or even a backup, copy them into the profile currently in use.

content:
Personally I think just flag it and ignore it.

The "threat" is identified as a javascript threat. Thunderbird does not run javascript on email bodies, like having ammunition in your home, it is not dangerous unless it is loaded in something that can make it go bang. Like Microsoft Outlook, which will execute the javascript. In Thunderbird all it does is consume a few bytes of space. Completely inert.

The file you have identified is a plain text file, It is an MBOX file (RD variant) with a small Mozilla twist in the formatting of the From line. MBOX is the default mail storage file format for Thunderbird. There is nothing to extract from it other than text so of course 7-zip is not going to extract anything, nor is Esets deep scan.

You can open the file and read it in windows notepad if you want to see what is in it. What you will see is the raw text that makes up the emails source in the folder one email following he other. essentially a stack of EML files. https://www.loc.gov/preservation/digital/formats/fdd/fdd000385.shtml

I have no idea what rubbish the Eset folk are selling you in their support, I did used the product until a couple of years ago and around 10 years ago it was very good. A couple of years ago I figured the money I was giving them for a load of alarmist warnings about javascript marketing and tracking code on web pages was a poor exchange. So now I use defender.

Generally antivirus scanners actually decode the mime portions of emails so they can examine the HTML body and attachments. Apparently Eset do not do this. Personally I wonder why they do this scanning at all in text files. For years I have been recommending to people that they exclude the Thunderbird profile from all scanning activity other than periodic scans, because A/V usually causes more issues with email than it solves ad this is a perfect example.

Eset have consumed your time, and now mine discussing what is in essence a false positive as it can not actually take any action on your computer unless you save the email as HTML and open it in a web browser. I am sure some people do that, but the A/V product will get two more bites of the apple, once when the HTML file is written/saved, and again when it is loaded in the web browser. They fed you full of rubbish about deep scans for a text file. What they think they can extract from a text file I have no idea at all.
creator: MattAuSupport

content:

content: Generally you insert an exclusion in your antivirus program from scanning in the Thunderbird profile folder while the application is running. With the files now not locked by scanning they can be updated and the mails should move.
creator: MattAuSupport

content:
If a previously working mail account stops working. Especially immediately after an update. Perhaps the worst thing you can do is remove the account and add it again in the hope some magic will happen and what did not work will start to.

Generally issues post update fall entirely at the door of your chosen antivirus product and it's attendant firewall component. Preventing them from messing with the connection though uninstalling them or running the operating system in safe mode with networking is the normal diagnostic for that. But as you have removed the accounts and we have none of the error message that would have occurred if there was a connection issue I am not even going to try and guess what the problem is.

Note that your test from webmail to webmail is not proving anything at all useful. It does not even isolate the issue to Thunderbird.

So do I guess we are now back to trying to diagnose why the new account wizard is not working for you? A log of what is happening would be most useful here. I documented how to log the wizard back in 2021 here https://thunderbirdtweaks.blogspot.com/2021/10/logging-new-account-wizard.html
creator: MattAuSupport
